titleStmt.title: M111 Set 1 of 3, [The Reader: But her own passion, the disgrace, the humiliation...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

sourceDesc.msDesc:
New York Public Library Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature m111-1 s
M111, Set 1 of 3 [The Reader: But her own passion, the disgrace, the humiliation...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5 fols.
Paginated 29-33.
p. 29 with discarded page paginated 34 on verso.
p. 30 with page from story on verso.
p. 32 with page from Between the Acts paginated 155 on verso.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
But Her own passion, the disgrace, the humiliation of her are all [actual?] in dumb shows family are all hidden under silence itself; or such flourishes and ornaments that reveal notning (nothing). After that amount to sielnce (silence). The plain country squires, the (they) are all teased once they take pen in hand by the demon of poetry. Af e (After) fl flxmxmxmxmxm floundering out a page of conceits and fanatsies (fantasies), Mr has indeed recourse to poetry. After trying to explain My conceit of this triple love, of affection passion and conjnuction (conjunction)" with a
w nedrin ([wandering?]) welt th (wealth) of imagery he quotes ... "... of lae
late I have light upon Mr Soensers (Spensers) opinion so rightly Soensers (Spensers) opinion so rightly agreeig (agreeing) with that which nature had taight (taught) me before, as the same might have been thought to have drawn out of his
discipline." It is the poets still who speak for the squires whocannot (who cannot) speak for themslces (themselves). Yet behind these
gfloird (florid) decorations, these strained elegancies, the wolves and foxes of the cort (court) prey and raven. Bastards are borb (born). There is a crude appetite a greed a passin (passion) which moves under the flowers and suddenly glares at us. Bastards are born in the flesh. Reputations are ruined. Only the people themlves (themselves) pass unseen. They too like the dramatists remain anonymous.

Yet there is a strange contradiction. If the wr country bgentlemen (gentlement) and their wives must speak in hyperbole when they write f (of) love, they write of possessions in plain English. No generation had more anxiety to preserve [illeg.] their physical bodies from decay. Theyeat (They eat) prodigously. They wear clothes that are so heavy they can scarcely move in them. Invenory (Inventory) after inventory records their furiture (furniture),

are all contrbutions (contributions) to our knowledge of what looked like, if you see him through a certain visoon (vision). But there always remains something further. It is this that lures the reader Abd (and) it is this quality that finally eludes us. gives him his perpetual vitality, he ecites (excites) perp tual (perpetual) curiosity. He does not as so many writers feed momentary appettites (appetites). The resder (reader) who has a dash of the writer in him, seeks out certain styles; certain forms. But Shakespere (Shakespeare) has nosuch (no such) appeal to the reader-writer. His styles are too innumerabel (innumerable) Perhpas (Perhaps) then he is chiefly used for more general piposes (purposes)--when the ink has gone dry upon the pen to revive the sense of langauge (language); or to testify, when words seem motiinless (motionless), to the enormous possibilities of speed. One reading always supersedes another Thus the trueest (truest) account of reading Shakespere (Shakespeare) would be not to write a book with a beginning middle and end; but to collect notes, without trying to make them consistent.

their jewels, their horses and carriages. When they die, heavy marble tombs are raised over them. The outer life is as substa tial (substantial) as cloth of gold and pigs capons hogs can make it. But the mind that lives in the head, the heart that hxxx speak only on the , through the mouths of the players.
Txmxmxmxmxmxmx

Yet in no age can there have been a deeper gulf between the artist and socity (society). dedicates his sonnets to Not one of all those highly eduvated (educated) nobles troubles to ask who is this patron? It is not a matter of interest in court circles. The plays are not discussed. Lord Southmapton (Southampton) and Lord Rutland, wrote to , pass away the time in London, merely in going to plays ev y (every) day" But the attraction of the stage called forth no comment. The players lived too far from the court to stir curiosity. They were too much of servants, too much of minstrels, jugglers nbear (bear) laeders (leaders) to be a proper topic for gossip. Thus the early works of
Shakeepare (Shakespeare) make no ripple in the pool of sielnce (silence). No one protests that here is an upstart writer who is for throwin (throwing) society into the melting pot. The grreat (great) might be mocked--that was the anicient (ancient) privilege of the court
jster (jester); or some scene from history re encated (reenacted). But the was quick to control irreverence. And in fact the dramatist wasn ot destroying society. The indignation that, after the first silent surprise, that for example stirred in London was partly the rage of those who felt that
stop in the middle of her song. and shut the piano.

Her father beat her oftener and oftner (oftener). She would show the marks on her flesh in the kitchen. "The squire didnt out to" said Pink the groom. xmxmxmxmxm Jinny the parlourmaid agreed would have agreed.; but her cough prevented her xxxx
Stxxx

There were many legs on the alwn lawn in the summer. She would watch them from between the rasperry (raspberry) canes, where she had a cave A grass path led between the bushes, and once the legs came walking there; and her brother(
ni (in) white flannel) stooped; and the girl in a white shkirt (skirt) who was with him stopped (stooped) too.

Hullo LElizabeth (Elizabeth)" said her brother. " VCut (Cut) alkng (along) into the houseand (house and) fetch my pipe; and I'll give you sipence (sixpence)" She guessed it was not his pipe he wanted; but to be rid of her. So she mooned round the library looking at the great pictures.

They had been in that house for ever so long. And the great pictures were almost part of the walls. They were ancestors; children; youths; grown men and women; sea captains; bishops. And the strange men used to look at them andmake (and make) notes in their pocket books.
The only person she saw whole, from her yellow head to her little black slippers, was Carry Elmer, the duag ter (daughter) of another squire.
At intervals of ten miles apart ther (there) were then great houses. Perry Hall, the E;mers (Elmers) house, was famous.

The Elizabethan audience were not readers. They had to draw in the play as they sat or stood at the playhouse, through their ears, through their eyes. There was no book of thee (the) words. They could not dxxxx deepen the impression, chew it over, and compare it, at a atble (table) in a private room. This perhaps exp;ains (explains) the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism; and the general nature of what [certain?] there is.
Bioth (Both) and deal with the neral (general) not with the particualr (particular); with the rules of compsition (composition), not with t e (the) details of one play or poem in partciualr (particular). It accounts too for the long pause between [sixteenth? seventeenth?] & the 18th centuries when the plays of
even hang suspended and unrealised. It was only when they had to [wait?] they were printed and the book of the words lay in many private rooms txxxx before they received their other life from the reader. Much that was lost in the playhous e (playhouse) was discovered in the private room. But much has also been lost , when the We have lost the sound of the spoken word; all that the sight of the actors body gives through the eye to the mind. We have lost too the sense of being part of the audience. We miss a thousand shades that the darmatistconveyed (dramatist conveyed)by inflection of voice, by gesture, by the palcing (placing) of the actors vbodies (bodies). This can still be tested, at least with Shakespeare, by comapring (comparing) whxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxx our impression xmxmxmxmxmxxx after seeing the p ay (play) with our impression after reading the play. But as the modern actor inevitably imports much that is of his own day, but foreign to Shshakespeare (Shakespeare), there is still something sunk beyond
beyond recall.

Presumably the earlier plays, in whichnthe (which the) pplaywright () was more at tge (the) mercy of the audience, are the more damaged by rreading (reading) them xmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxx The reader instinctively tries to be there in person. He tries to sup ly (supply) the trumepts (trumpets) and the flags; the citizens and the apprentices. He furbishes himself nourishes himself with a dip into , with a dip into . He makes an effort to sppply (supply) what is so obviously the sunk part of the play. But he is perp (perpetually)
tually (perpetually) rebuffed. He is apt pat to become not a reader but a student; txmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmmxmxmx a collector of scattered bones. At some point however in the Elizabethan drama the rezder (reader) is born. There are spepeches (speeches) and scnes (scenes) that call upon his special faculty. When the dramatist becomes conscious of the play as a work of art; when he becomes able to unite the play by a unity which is not that of the plot-- by something in himself his [illeg.], his [illeg.] by some individuality of his style, of his whole temper, It is the apprehension of this power at work it is this apprehension that serves to drow (draw) together the faculties which are proper to the reader.
th t (that) brings the reader into being.

The reader has been in existence for round about four hubdred (hundred) years. But his life hisotry (history) is an obscure one. At some point his ear must have lost its a uten (acuteness) acuteness; then his eyes became dull. Then he became word conscious, aware of suggestions and echoes. As time paassed (passed), he imported into the writteh (written) word much that was unintended by the writer. A word spelt in the Elizabethan

ho mes (homes) will be built. Each flat with With refrigerators in each flat? xmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxm xxxx And churches... The tune changed. It chopped and changed. It broke off. It broke up. Withthe (With the) means at he (her) dispoal (disposal) you couldnt ask too
mcu (much). Thxmxmxmxmxmxmx; What a cackle; a cocophony (cacophony)... like the yaffle, a they call the woodpecker. The laughing bird who flits from tree to tree. Out they skipped. Children? Imps --elfs... Out they skipped. The riff raff of the village... Holding what? Tin cans? Bed room candle sticks? Shaving glasses? Old tobbaco (tabacco) jars? My dear, thats the
cehval (cheval) glass from the rectory... and the mirror-- I lent her. My motgers (mother's)... And grabdpas (grandpa's) old top hat! Whats the notion? Anything thats bright enough, presumably, to refelct (reflect)...
Thats the mens shaving glass from the stable.. Mrs Sands, did you really lend her that?
Ourselves Ourselves?

the meaning of words is tremendously developed; so that they remain attached to certain aspects of the printed page; the sch ars (scholars) the students whxmxmxmxmxmxx, Again there is the very large class of perfectly literatue (literate) peole (people) whorun (who run) their eyes over miles of print yearly, yet never read a w word. Txmxmxmxxx The reader, distinct from the schoar (scholar), distinct from the print stripper of news paper print, has a curious p wer (power) to make houses and countries visible, men and womn (women) and their thoughts and emotion, from marks on a piece of paper. His faculty is always changig (changing) The reader agains (again) is always changing. The is now
develpojg (developing) his eyes, the is dev pojg (developing) his ear. He is still in existence; for it is a fact that he is still casuing (causing) books to be printed. He is still reading Sjakespere (Shakespeare).
